questions.text: Perimortem CS done at
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Upper segment Perimortem CS - done when there is sudden collapse ? start CPR FOR 4 MINS ? CANNOT REVIVE ? EMERGENCY CS. [ upper segment] During Cesarean Section, CPR has to continue. Perimortem Cesarean Section (PMCS) is an emergency procedure performed during maternal cardiac arrest to improve survival chances for both the mother and fetus. Key Points: • Timing: Ideally performed within 4-5 minutes of cardiac arrest to maximize outcomes. • Indications: Maternal cardiac arrest with: • Gestational age ?20 weeks (fundal height above the umbilicus). • No response to advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) after 4 minutes. • Rationale: Relieves aortocaval compression, improves maternal circulation and oxygenation, and provides the fetus with a chance of survival. • Procedure: • Perform midline vertical incision to expedite delivery. • Focus on rapid extraction of the fetus. • Outcome Goals: Restore maternal cardiac output and save the fetus, if viable.

questions.text: SSRI in pregnancy causes (multiple correct) A. ADHD B. Low apgar C. Pulmonary hypertension D. Delayed motor development
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B, C, D -SSRIs like sertraline are the most commonly used anti-depressants to treat depression in pregnant women . -SSRIS and maternal depression have both been found to cause a low APGAR score. -The development of ADHD in the newborn has been found to be associated with untreated maternal depression. But studies regarding SSRIs having a casual association with the development of ADHD have been inconclusive. -When used in the 2nd trimester in pregnancy, SSRIs have been associated with risk of precipitating Persistent Pulmonary Hypertension in the newborn . -There has been evidence of a transient delay in development milestones in patients who are exposed to SSRIs during pregnancy. Most studies have observed that the development returns to normal after some time .

questions.text: Kassowitz rule is related to?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Remove previous explanation and add this Kassowitz’s Law in Primary Syphilis Kassowitz’s Law states that with each successive pregnancy in an untreated syphilitic mother, the severity of congenital syphilis in the newborn decreases, and the likelihood of fetal infection or stillbirth reduces. Application in Primary Syphilis: • This law is not directly applicable to primary syphilis but is relevant to congenital syphilis in untreated mothers. • In primary syphilis, the mother has a high bacterial load, increasing the risk of transplacental transmission if the pregnancy occurs during this stage. • If left untreated, repeated pregnancies may result in milder infections or unaffected newborns, due to a declining spirochete load and partial maternal immunity.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Mannings score except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Biophysical profile scoring The BPP score consists of the combined evaluation of fetal tone, gross body movement, breathing movement, amniotic fluid volume and heart-rate reactivity. BPP score can predict both fetal pH and outcome26,27. The relationship between altered BPP score and fetal pH seems to be consistent across gestational ages26. A score of < 4 is associated with a fetal ph ≤ 7.20, while a score of < 2 has a sensitivity of 100% for acidemia27. This correlation remains highly significant even when using a simplified BPP that is based on assessment of only fetal heart rate and amniotic fluid volume28

questions.text: From 'Adluminal to luminal, arrange the following series of events in spermatogenesis ? A. Myoepithelial cells B. Spermatogonia C. Primary spermatocyte D. Spermatid E. Secondary spermatocyte
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A, B, C, E, D Sperms made in testes are non- motile. Only once they undergo maturation in epididymis [motility], the spermatid converts to? spermatozoa. The formation of sperm cells (spermatogenesis) follows a well-defined sequence of cell differentiation. Here is the order of formation: 1. Spermatogonia (Diploid, 2n): • Stem cells located in the basal compartment of the seminiferous tubules. • Divide by mitosis to produce more spermatogonia and primary spermatocytes. 2. Primary Spermatocyte (Diploid, 2n): • Formed from spermatogonia after mitotic division. • Undergo meiosis I to produce secondary spermatocytes. 3. Secondary Spermatocyte (Haploid, n): • Result of meiosis I, containing half the genetic material (haploid). • Undergo meiosis II to form spermatids. 4. Spermatid (Haploid, n): • Immature, round haploid cells produced by meiosis II. • Undergo morphological changes during spermiogenesis to become spermatozoa. 5. Spermatozoa (Haploid, n): • Fully mature, motile sperm cells capable of fertilization.

questions.text: Which of the following cervical cerclage procedure should be done in a non pregnant female with cervical incompetence?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Laparoscopic cerclage It is an abdominal surgery done at the level of ISTHMUS ? more effective than vaginal surgery. Lash & Lash cerclage is a vaginal surgery. Wurms cerclage is done in pregnancy, vaginal surgery, also called as emergency cerclage ? when the cervix is fully dilated, membranes are intact. In non-pregnant women, a laparoscopic cerclage is the preferred choice when a cervical cerclage is indicated, particularly in cases of: • Recurrent second-trimester losses due to cervical insufficiency. • Failed vaginal cerclage in previous pregnancies. • Anatomical abnormalities, such as a congenitally short or damaged cervix. Advantages of Laparoscopic Cerclage: 1. High Success Rates: Offers better outcomes for future pregnancies compared to other techniques. 2. Placement at the Internal Os: Provides a more secure and anatomically correct cerclage. 3. Minimally Invasive: Lower morbidity and faster recovery compared to open surgery. 4. Avoids Vaginal Complications: Eliminates the risk of vaginal infection or trauma associated with vaginal cerclage techniques

questions.text: WHO guidelines for second stage of labour
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hot compresses to perineum The World Health Organization (WHO) provides recommendations to minimize perineal trauma during the second stage of labor: 1. Birth Position: • Encourage women to adopt a birth position of their choice, including upright positions, as this can influence perineal outcomes. 2. Pushing Techniques: • Support spontaneous, non-directed pushing, allowing the woman to follow her natural urge. 3. Perineal Techniques: • Utilize methods such as perineal massage and warm compresses to reduce the risk of perineal tears. 4. Episiotomy Policy: • Avoid routine or liberal use of episiotomy; reserve for specific clinical indications. 5. Fundal Pressure: • Do not apply manual fundal pressure to expedite birth, as it may increase the risk of perineal trauma.

questions.text: Milk production in pregnancy is inhibited by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) High Estrogen PROLACTIN LEVELS - HIGHEST IN PREGNANCY, still no milk production because of negative feedback from Estrogen & progesterone. Single best answer- progesterone > estrogen. After delivery - prolactin falls by 50%. 1st stimulus for Initiation of lactation ? sudden fall of E & P. [Progesterone more than Estrogen] milk production during pregnancy is inhibited by the high levels of estrogen and progesterone. Mechanism: 1. Estrogen: • Stimulates the growth and development of the ductal system in the mammary glands. • Inhibits the secretion of prolactin at the receptor level, preventing milk production. 2. Progesterone: • Promotes alveolar development in the breasts. • Blocks the action of prolactin on the alveolar cells, preventing lactation. Onset of Lactation: • After delivery, levels of estrogen and progesterone drop significantly, removing the inhibitory effect. • Prolactin, released from the anterior pituitary, stimulates milk production. • Suckling further promotes milk ejection through the oxytocin-mediated milk let-down reflex.

questions.text: 20 weeks female with the following anomaly. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Anencephaly is a severe neural tube defect (NTD) characterized by the partial or complete absence of the brain, skull, and scalp due to failure of the anterior (cranial) neural tube to close during early embryonic development (around the 3rd to 4th week of gestation). Clinical Features: • Absent skull and brain tissue – Only rudimentary brain structures may be present. • Frog-like facies – Prominent eyes due to lack of skull vault. • Open cranial defect – The neural tissue may be exposed or covered by a thin membrane. • Polyhydramnios (excess amniotic fluid) – Due to impaired fetal swallowing reflex. • Stillbirth or early neonatal death – The condition is lethal, with most affected infants dying within hours to days after birth. Diagnosis: • Ultrasound (USG): • Detectable as early as 10 -14 weeks gestation. • Absence of the cranial vault (”froglike appearance”). • Polyhydramnios. • Maternal Serum Alpha-Fetoprotein (MSAFP): • Elevated due to neural tissue exposure to amniotic fluid. • Amniotic Fluid Analysis: • Increased acetylcholinesterase (AChE) levels confirm an open neural tube defect. Failure of neural tube closure leads to absence of the forebrain (cerebrum), skull bones, and scalp. • The brainstem may be present but is underdeveloped. • The exposed brain tissue undergoes degeneration, resulting in anencephaly.

questions.text: Complication Specific To Monochorionic Twins
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) TTTS Seen in monochorionic diamniotic twins, [formed on 4th to 8th day post fertilization], most common type of monozygotic twins. Deep artery to deep vein anastomosis causes TTTS. QUINTERO STAGING is used. Treatment- laser ablation of vascular anastomosis Diagnosis on USG - Polyhydramnios in 1 baby & oligohydramnios in another baby simultaneously. Key Features: 1. Donor Twin: • Transfers blood to the recipient twin. • Develops anemia, growth restriction, and oligohydramnios (stuck twin). 2. Recipient Twin: • Receives excess blood. • Develops polycythemia, polyhydramnios, and can experience heart failure due to fluid overload. Diagnosis: • Ultrasound findings: • Discordant amniotic fluid levels (oligohydramnios in one sac and polyhydramnios in the other). • Growth discordance. • Doppler abnormalities. Management: • Mild Cases: Close monitoring with serial ultrasounds. • Severe Cases: • Laser Ablation: Targets abnormal placental vessels (gold standard). • Amnioreduction: Temporarily reduces polyhydramnios. • Delivery: Depending on gestational age and severity.

questions.text: Which of the following is group 1 in Robson classification for CS
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Nulliparous with spontaneous labour In 2015, WHO proposed the use of the Robson classi?cation (also known as the 10-group classi?cation) as a global standard for assessing, monitoring and comparing caesarean section rates both within healthcare facilities and between them. The system classifies all women into one of 10 categories that are mutually exclusive and, as a set, totally comprehensive. The categories are based on 5 basic obstetric characteristics that are routinely collected in all maternities (parity, number of foetuses, previous caesarean section, onset of labour, gestational age, and fetal presentation).

questions.text: A pregnant woman has leg cramps at night. What will you tell the patient to do
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Dorsiflexion and knee extension Leg cramps are common usually occurring during later half of pregnancy. The cramps are due to painful muscle contractions and generally experienced in calves at night. They are thought to be secondary to build up of lactic and pyruvic acid leading to involuntary contraction of affected muscles but exact etiology is unknown. If a cramp occurs calf stretches – straightening of leg and flex the toes towards shin (dorsiflexion) as soon as cramps begin may be helpful. Other nonpharmacologic modalities include increase hydration, regukar exercises, ice massage , hot shower or a warm tub bath

questions.text: Which virus has following pathophysiology and causes microcephaly in fetus-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Zika Hoff Bauer cells seen - fetal macrophages in placenta. To know about fetal infection - amniotic fluid PCR analysis is done. Zika virus infects the cells that strongly express TIM-1 a cell surface phosphatidylserine and phosphatidylethanolamine receptor. zika virus replicates in the glandular epithelium of decidua and infects invasive cytotrophoblast, placental macrophages hofbauer cells and fetal ?broblasts. Hoffbauer cells contribute to the spread of zika virus. Zika virus is associated with major adverse fetal and neonatal outcomes including microcephaly Zika virus is transmitted by bite of infected aedes mosquito. Both dermal fibroblast and epidermal keratinocytes are targets of zika virus potentially transmitting the infection to dermal dendritic cells (langerhan cells) thereby facilitating zika virus spread.

questions.text: P/V was done by nurse and cord prolapsed what is the first step you will do
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stepwise Management of Cord Prolapse: 1. Call for Help: • Activate the obstetric emergency team immediately. 2. Relieve Cord Compression: • Positioning: Place the patient in knee-chest or Trendelenburg position to reduce pressure on the cord. • Manual Elevation: Use a sterile, gloved hand to elevate the presenting part (head or buttocks) off the cord and maintain until delivery. • Bladder Filling: Instill 500-700 mL of warm saline into the bladder to lift the presenting part. 3. Avoid Handling the Cord: • Minimize manipulation of the cord to prevent vasospasm and further compromise. 4. Maintain Cord Warmth: • If the cord is outside the vagina, cover it with warm, saline-soaked gauze to prevent drying and vasoconstriction. 5. Assess Fetal Status: • Continuous fetal heart rate monitoring to detect bradycardia or distress. 6. Expedite Delivery: • Emergency Cesarean Section: Preferred and definitive management. • Vaginal Delivery: Only if delivery is imminent and feasible or if the fetus is already dead

questions.text: All the following are components of biophysical profile except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Contraction stress test There are 5 components of BPP or Mannings score; these are 1. Fetal breathing movements 2. Gross body movements 3. Fetal tone 4. NST 5. Amniotic fluid 1. Score of 10/10 or 8/10 : normal 2. Score of 6/10 with normal liquor : equivocal ? repeat test on the same day 3. Score less than or equal to 4/10 : immediate Termination Of Pregnancy [CS]. The Biophysical Profile (BPP) is a prenatal test used to assess fetal well-being, combining ultrasound parameters and fetal heart rate monitoring. It evaluates five components: Components of the Biophysical Profile: 1. Fetal Breathing Movements: • At least 1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting ?30 seconds within 30 minutes. 2. Fetal Movements: • At least 3 discrete body or limb movements within 30 minutes. 3. Fetal Tone: • At least 1 episode of active extension and flexion of a limb or trunk (e.g., opening and closing of a hand). 4. Amniotic Fluid Volume (AFV): • A single vertical pocket of amniotic fluid measuring ?2 cm or an amniotic fluid index (AFI) ?5 cm. 5. Non-Stress Test (NST): • Reactive fetal heart rate pattern with ?2 accelerations of ?15 bpm lasting at least 15 seconds within 20 minutes. Scoring: • Each component is scored as 2 (normal) or 0 (abnormal). • Maximum score: 10/10 (if NST is included) or 8/8 (without NST). Interpretation: • 8–10: Normal (low risk of fetal asphyxia). • 6: Equivocal; consider repeating or additional testing. • ?4: Abnormal; immediate evaluation and potential delivery recommended.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of bishops score
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Type of pelvis Components of bishops score are Cervical dilatation, Cervical effacement/length, Cervical position, Cervical consistency and station of head. Cervical dilatation is the most important component. Position is the least important component. Modified Bishops is when cervical effacement is replaced with cervical length. Simplified Bishops - 3 components : Dilatation, effacement, station. The Bishop Score is used to assess cervical readiness for labor and predict the success of induction. It evaluates five components related to the cervix and fetal position: Components of the Bishop Score: 1. Cervical Dilation (cm): • 0 cm = 0 points • 1–2 cm = 1 point • 3–4 cm = 2 points • ?5 cm = 3 points 2. Cervical Effacement (%): • 0–30% = 0 points • 40–50% = 1 point • 60–70% = 2 points • ?80% = 3 points 3. Cervical Consistency: • Firm = 0 points • Medium = 1 point • Soft = 2 points 4. Cervical Position: • Posterior = 0 points • Midposition = 1 point • Anterior = 2 points 5. Fetal Station (relative to ischial spines): • -3 = 0 points • -2 = 1 point • -1/0 = 2 points • +1/+2 = 3 points Scoring Interpretation: • ?6: Unfavorable cervix; induction may require cervical ripening. • ?9: Favorable cervix; high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text: Which is the criteria for abdominal ectopic pregnancy ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Studdiford Studdiford criteria are the criteria for primary abdominal pregnancy. While spiegelberg are criteria for primary ovarian pregnancy. Rubins and Paalmanns are criteria for primary cervical pregnancy Studdiford Criteria for Primary Abdominal Pregnancy: 1. Normal Tubes and Ovaries: • The fallopian tubes and ovaries must be intact and show no evidence of rupture or ectopic implantation. 2. Absence of Uteroperitoneal Fistula: • There should be no connection between the uterine cavity and the peritoneal cavity. 3. Primary Peritoneal Implantation: • The pregnancy must be implanted directly on a peritoneal surface. Spiegelberg Criteria for Primary Ovarian Pregnancy: 1. Gestational Sac in the Ovary: • The pregnancy must be located within the ovarian tissue. 2. Connection to the Uterus: • The ectopic gestation must be attached to the uterus via the ovarian ligament. 3. Intact Fallopian Tube: • The fallopian tube on the affected side must be normal and not involved in the pregnancy. 4. Ovarian Tissue in the Wall of the Gestational Sac: • Histological evidence of ovarian tissue must be present in the sac wall after surgical removal.

questions.text: 28 year old G2P1with 8 months amenorrhea presented with pain abdomen, bleeding per vaginum, loss of fetal movements with history of preeclampsia.
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Abruption This is the classic history of abruption placenta which is characterised by painful antepartum bleeding, preeclampsia is a risk factor for abruption. Separation of placenta from underlying decidua causes hypoxia to fetus and hence fetal compromise. SMOKING is protective for preeclampsia. Most common complication of Preeclampsia is abruption. Preeclampsia & placenta previa have negative association. Key Features of Placental Abruption: Placental abruption is the premature separation of a normally implanted placenta before delivery, leading to maternal and fetal complications. The main features are: 1. Clinical Features: 1. Vaginal Bleeding: • Usually dark red in color. • May be absent in concealed abruption. 2. Abdominal Pain: • Sudden, severe, constant pain. • May be localized or diffuse. 3. Uterine Tenderness: • The uterus is firm, tender, and rigid on palpation. 4. Hypertonic Uterus: • Frequent, strong contractions or a “board-like” uterus. 5. Fetal Distress or Death: • Non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns or absent fetal heart sounds in severe cases. 2. Risk Factors: • Hypertension (chronic or preeclampsia). • Trauma (e.g., abdominal injury, motor vehicle accidents). • Smoking, cocaine use. • Multiparity. • History of previous abruption. 3. Diagnosis: 1. Clinical Diagnosis: Based on symptoms and physical examination. 2. Ultrasound: Limited sensitivity but may show retroplacental hematoma. 3. Laboratory Tests: • Kleihauer-Betke Test: Detects fetal-maternal hemorrhage. • Coagulopathy (e.g., DIC) in severe cases. 4. Complications: 1. Maternal: • Hemorrhagic shock. • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC). • Uterine rupture. 2. Fetal: • Hypoxia, acidosis. • Intrauterine fetal death (IUFD).

questions.text: 28 year old lady with 6 weeks amenorrhea with pain abdomen and bleeding p/v. her UPT Is positive. TVS shows empty uterus and no free fluid in POD. What is the next line of management
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Follow up with beta HCG This is a case of early pregnancy. It could be normal intrauterine pregnancy or non viable or ectopic pregnancy. The usg shows empty uterus which can be seen with early intrauterine pregnancy or ectopic hence we need the follow up with HCG to look for critical value, we will need serial HCG values and repeat usg for her. If we see a rise - Doubling → intrauterine pregnancy If we see a Plateau → suggestive of ectopic. Diagnosis of ectopic can only be made on USG. CONFIRMED BY USG- extrauterine gestational sac with embryo or cardiac activity.

questions.text: ESR in pregnancy increase because of
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Fibrinogen Erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) increases during pregnancy, primarily due to elevated levels of fibrinogen. Key Points: 1. Physiological Changes in Pregnancy: • During pregnancy, fibrinogen (Factor I) levels rise significantly as part of the normal hypercoagulable state. • Increased fibrinogen enhances the aggregation of red blood cells, leading to a higher ESR. 2. Other Contributing Factors: • Elevated levels of immunoglobulins and pregnancy hormones. • Hemodilution from increased plasma volume.

questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Suction curettage This is a patient with complete molar pregnancy as documented on usg showing snowstorm appearance. Management of complete mole if family is not complete is suction evacuation while if family is complete we can go for hysterectomy. Follow up with HCG, period of surveillance : 6 months. Contraception of choice is OCP Not given is an IUD. On SE, patient is high risk : >40 years Bilateral large theca lutein cysts Fundal height is more than POG HCG >10?. We give them prophylactic chemotherapy : methotrexate or actinomycin-D.

questions.text: 26 year old lady was on antithyroid drugs. Following delivery infant diagnosed with aplasia cutis. What is the drug
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Methimazole Thionamides are drug of choice for hyperthyroidism in pregnancy , in the first trimester methimazole should not be given as it causes aplasia cutis in the newborn. Other anomalies like tracheoesophageal fistula, omplaocele choanal atresia and patent vitellointestinal duct have also been reported with methimazole and carbimazole but not with PTU Hence drug of choice for first trimester hyperthyroidism is PTU while in second and third trimester its methimazole

questions.text: In Atonic PPH, which of the following is done: A. Uterine massage is first step in the management B. Suction of uterus C. IV Methyl Ergometrine is given to all patients D. B-Lynch suture is put if medical management fails
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) If A and D are correct Bimanual uterine massage + uterotonics given simultaneously. Methylergometrine is given IM, NOT IV. CI of Methylergometrine : preeclampsia, heart disease B-lynch sutures put when vitals are stable. If medical management fails and vitals are unstable → stepwise pelvic devascularization : bilateral uterine artery ligation → bilateral ovarian artery ligation → bilateral ligation of anterior division of internal Iliac artery → hysterectomy. B-Lynch sutures are only effective for atonic PPH, applied on uterus, are called as compression sutures.

questions.text: Name the sign in which you see gas in big vessel and heart
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Robert sign SEEN BY 12 HOURS AFTER FETAL DEATH. SPAULDING SIGN - seen by 7 days. Ball sign - hyperflexion of fetal spine All the above are signs of IUD baby. Robert Sign • Description: Presence of gas in the fetal circulatory system, especially in the great vessels or heart. • Timing: Seen as early as 12 hours after intrauterine fetal death (IUFD) but more commonly after 1–2 days. • Significance: Indicative of IUFD, not to be confused with hydrops. Halo Sign • Description: Refers to scalp edema appearing as a hypoechoic “halo” around the fetal skull. • Significance: • In the context of hydrops fetalis, the halo sign is caused by generalized subcutaneous edema. • In IUFD, it can indicate fetal maceration in prolonged demise. Ball Sign • Description: This refers to the shape of the fetus appearing like a ball, caused by loss of normal posture and tone in cases of severe fetal maceration or prolonged IUFD. • Significance: Seen in late-stage IUFD where the fetus assumes a rounded, curled posture due to soft tissue breakdown and loss of musculoskeletal integrity.

questions.text: True/False regarding the management fo A 36 weeks primigravida female diagnosed with Transverse lie: A. Repeat USG to confirm the position B. Prepared for CS at onset of labor C. First breech part is extracted during CS D. Most probable cause in this case is placenta previa E. Admit at 36 weeks
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) A-T, B-F, C-T, D-T, E-F Repeat USG done to rule out placenta previa Transverse lie & in early labor → ECV done : membranes intact. Transverse lie patient in active labor → cesarean section. Most common cause of Transverse lie is prematurity Most common cause of Transverse lie at term is placenta previa. PATIENT in Transverse lie & not in labor → Admit patient at 37 [to 38 weeks] → ECV → ECV successful but there is reversion → try ECV again at 38-39 weeks → a. successful → do induction of labour, b. if unsuccessful → elective cesarean section. 2nd twin Transverse lie → can do both internal podalic version & ECV if requirements are met. Otherwise we do an internal podalic version followed by breech extraction.

questions.text: A fetus was found to have congenital heart block what should be evaluated in the mother?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) SLE. Patient should conceive only if disease has been inactive for 6 months. Active SLE at conception : strong predictor of adverse outcome High risk for SLE FLARE in pregnancy : primigravida, lupus nephritis, active disease at conception Complications in pregnancy : Preeclampsia Abortions Preterm labour IUGR Neonatal lupus - Cutaneous lesions, complete heart block [Anti Ro & Anti LA positive] : upto 2% risk. Once the patient has conceived : hydroxychloroquine should be continued : reduces flare risk and risk of complete heart block. Low dose aspirin given as well. NSAIDS Prednisone given during flare Azathioprine 2mg/day can be given Cyclosporine may be given Drugs Contraindicated in pregnancy : 1. Cyclophosphamide 2. Methotrexate 3. Mycophenolate mofetil 4. Leflunomide

questions.text: In preterm labour which drug has Neuro-protective role?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) MgSO4 Given Only if pregnancy is <32weeks. Option C & D are beta agonists, not used now. Only beta agonist used now is terbutaline. They cause tachycardia, tremors, hyperglycemia, hypokalemia arrhythmia, cardiac arrest, pulmonary edema. Magnesium sulfate (MgSO?) plays a critical role in neuroprotection for preterm infants by reducing the risk of cerebral palsy and other severe neurologic disabilities. It is recommended for women at risk of imminent preterm birth. Mechanism of Action: 1. Stabilization of Neuronal Cells: • Magnesium acts as an NMDA (N-methyl-D-aspartate) receptor antagonist, reducing excitotoxicity caused by glutamate release during hypoxic or ischemic injury. 2. Reduction of Inflammation: • Magnesium sulfate suppresses inflammatory cytokines and oxidative stress, protecting developing neural tissues. 3. Improvement of Cerebral Blood Flow: • Maintains vascular integrity and reduces vasoconstriction in fetal cerebral vessels, minimizing hypoxic damage. 4. Prevention of Apoptosis: • Protects neurons from programmed cell death caused by ischemic injury. Indications: • Administered to women at gestational ages between 24+0 and 31+6 weeks who are: • At risk of imminent preterm birth (delivery expected within 24 hours). • Carrying a singleton or multiple pregnancy. Administration: • Loading Dose: 4 g intravenously over 30 minutes. • Maintenance Dose: 1 g/hour infusion until delivery or for 24 hours (whichever comes first). Benefits: • Reduction in Cerebral Palsy: • Reduces the risk by approximately 30-40% in preterm infants. • Improvement in Motor Outcomes: • Decreases severity of motor dysfunction in survivors.

questions.text: Sequential arrangement of fetal scans done in pregnancy: 1. Triple markers 2. Nuchal Translucency Scan 3. Growth scan 4. Anomalous scan
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 2→1→4→3 Nuchal Translucency Scan done between 11-13+6 WEEKS Triple markers done between 15-22weeks [MOST commonly 16-18 weeks] Anomaly scan 18-22weeks (Level 2), done for all pregnant women, also done in gestational diabetes mellitus. Growth scan done in 3rd trimester, best marker for growth is abdominal circumference.

Cutaneous scars, IUGR, NEUROLOGICAL & LIMB ABNORMALITIES seen. VARICELLA IN PREGNANCY : ORAL ACYCLOVIR given VARICELLA PNEUMONIA : IV ACYCLOVIR given VARICELLA EXPOSURE : PEP : varizig : immunoprophylaxis given VACCINE : VARIVAX is contraindicated in pregnancy as it is a live vaccine MMR, HPV are also contraindicated in pregnancy Neonatal varicella : pregnant woman acquires infection between 5 days before delivery to 2 days after delivery.

Contraindications : 1. suspected pregnancy 2. History of thrombosis 3. Active liver disease 4. Known case of breast cancer 5. Undiagnosed vaginal bleeding

questions.text: Which of the trophoblast does not invade spiral arterioles:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Interstitial Endovascular does the vascular remodeling In normal vascular remodeling during early pregnancy, interstitial trophoblasts (a subset of extravillous trophoblasts) play a crucial role, but their function is distinct from endovascular trophoblasts. Here’s the clarification: Role of Interstitial and Endovascular Trophoblasts: 1. Interstitial Trophoblasts: • Invade the decidual stroma and the walls of spiral arteries. • Help in disrupting the muscular layer of the spiral arteries, leading to loss of vascular tone and elasticity. • However, they do not migrate into the lumen of the spiral arteries. 2. Endovascular Trophoblasts: • Invade the lumen of the spiral arteries. • Replace the endothelial lining and partially occlude the lumen temporarily to reduce blood flow velocity, ensuring optimal placental perfusion. Importance of Trophoblast Function: • Proper remodeling of spiral arteries into low-resistance, high-capacitance vessels is critical for adequate placental and fetal perfusion. • Failure of interstitial or endovascular trophoblasts to remodel the spiral arteries is associated with conditions like preeclampsia and intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR).

questions.text: A diabetic female delivers head of the baby even after one minute the shoulder was not delivered. Which of the following is done?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) McRoberts maneuver Classical presentation of Shoulder dystocia. Turtle sign is seen First maneuver done is McRoberts maneuver : sudden flexion & abduction. This maneuver does not change the diameters of the pelvis, it only increases available space by straightening the sacrum. By this, Pubic symphysis moves cranially. Nerve injured by this maneuver is lateral Cutaneous nerve of thigh : causes meralgia paresthetica. Second step is applying suprapubic pressure, never fundal pressure.

choices.text: Total lung capacity increased by approximately 5% by term

questions.text: Physiological change in respiratory system in pregnancy?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) FRC decreased Minute ventilation increases Reserve volume & residual volume: decrease TLC : slightly decreases. Unaffected : RR, VC, IRV Tidal volume increases During pregnancy, significant respiratory physiological changes occur to meet the increased oxygen demands of the mother and fetus. These changes are driven by hormonal, mechanical, and metabolic factors. Key Respiratory Changes in Pregnancy: 1. Structural Changes: • Diaphragm Elevation: • The growing uterus elevates the diaphragm by ~4 cm, reducing lung capacity. • Rib Cage Changes: • Increased rib cage diameter due to relaxation of ligaments (mediated by progesterone). • Thoracic Compliance: • Slight decrease in compliance but compensated by other adaptations. 2. Pulmonary Volumes and Capacities: • Tidal Volume (TV): • Increases by ~30–50%, leading to increased ventilation. • Minute Ventilation: • Increases by ~40%, due to increased tidal volume. • Residual Volume (RV): • Decreases by ~20%, due to diaphragm elevation. • Functional Residual Capacity (FRC): • Decreases by ~20–30%. • Total Lung Capacity (TLC): • Decreases slightly (by ~5%) due to diaphragm displacement. 3. Gas Exchange: • Oxygen Consumption: • Increases by ~20–30% to meet the metabolic demands of the mother and fetus. • PaCO?: • Decreases to ~27–32 mmHg (chronic respiratory alkalosis) due to increased ventilation. • PaO?: • Increases slightly (~100–110 mmHg) due to hyperventilation. • pH: • Mild alkalosis (~7.40–7.45). 4. Progesterone’s Role: • Acts as a respiratory stimulant, increasing the sensitivity of the respiratory center to carbon dioxide and driving hyperventilation.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of management of 3rd stage of labour
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Uterine massage Early Cord Clamping is a better answer than uterine massage. The World Health Organization (WHO) recommends Active Management of the Third Stage of Labour (AMTSL) to prevent postpartum hemorrhage (PPH). The key components are: Components of AMTSL (as per WHO): 1. Administration of Uterotonic: • A uterotonic drug should be given immediately after the delivery of the baby. • Preferred Uterotonic: Oxytocin, 10 IU intramuscularly. • Alternatives (if oxytocin is unavailable): Misoprostol, ergometrine, or a combination drug. 2. Controlled Cord Traction (CCT): • Gentle traction on the umbilical cord while supporting the uterus to assist delivery of the placenta. • Ensure the uterus is well contracted before applying traction. 3. Uterine Massage (if needed): • Massage is not routine but should be done if there is uterine atony. 4. Examination of the Placenta and Uterus: • Inspect the placenta and membranes to ensure complete expulsion. • Palpate the uterus to ensure it is firm and contracted.

questions.text: When to shift patient with prosthetic heart valves on heparin from warfarin
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 36wks Switch from warfarin to heparin in the 1st trimester if the dose is more than 5 mg/day or at 36 weeks. If the patient is on warfarin & goes in labour ? cesarean section done under general anesthesia. In pregnant women with heart disease on warfarin (e.g., for mechanical heart valves or atrial fibrillation), the timing of switching from warfarin to low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) is crucial to balance maternal and fetal safety. When to Switch: 1. Early Pregnancy (Weeks 6–12): • Warfarin is teratogenic (risk of warfarin embryopathy and fetal anomalies), so: • Switch to LMWH or unfractionated heparin (UFH) as soon as pregnancy is confirmed or ideally by 6 weeks of gestation. • Continue LMWH until 12 weeks, after the period of organogenesis. 2. Second Trimester (After 12Weeks): • In selected high-risk cases (e.g., mechanical heart valves), warfarin may be restarted after organogenesis, as it is more effective in preventing thromboembolism. Close monitoring is essential. 3. Near Delivery (36 Weeks or Earlier): • Switch from warfarin to LMWH or UFH around 36 weeks to minimize the risk of warfarin-induced fetal hemorrhage during delivery. • Stop LMWH 24 hours before labor or planned delivery and transition to short-acting UFH if needed. Key Considerations: • Fetal Risks: Warfarin carries risks of embryopathy (nasal hypoplasia, stippled epiphyses) and fetal bleeding, especially in the first trimester. • Maternal Risks: LMWH is safer during pregnancy but may have slightly reduced efficacy in certain high-risk heart conditions, requiring individualized management. • Monitoring: • LMWH: Adjust doses based on anti-Xa levels. • Warfarin: Maintain INR within a therapeutic range (usually 2.5–3.5 for mechanical heart valves).

questions.text: WHO recommended emergency contraception ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Lng 1.5 miligm Or 0.75mgs twice, 12 hours apart within the first 72 hours. WHO’s recommendations: 1. Definition of Emergency Contraception Emergency contraceptives are methods used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected sexual intercourse or contraceptive failure. They are intended for use within a few days after the event and are not meant as a regular contraceptive method. 2. Types of Emergency Contraceptives WHO recommends the following types of ECs: • Oral emergency contraceptive pills (ECPs): • Levonorgestrel (LNG) pills: A single dose of 1.5 mg or two doses of 0.75 mg taken 12 hours apart, ideally within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. • Ulipristal acetate (UPA) pills: A single 30 mg dose, effective up to 120 hours (5 days) after unprotected sex. • Copper intrauterine device (IUD): • Can be inserted up to 5 days after unprotected sex and provides highly effective, long-term contraception. . Yuzpe Regimen: • Combination Pills: High-dose combined oral contraceptive pills (COCs) containing ethinylestradiol (estrogen) and levonorgestrel or norgestrel (progestin) can be used. • Dosage: Two doses of COCs are taken 12 hours apart: • The first dose should be taken as soon as possible after unprotected intercourse (ideally within 72 hours). • Each dose typically contains 100 ?g of ethinylestradiol and 0.5 mg of levonorgestrel (or equivalent). 3. Effectiveness and Safety • Emergency contraceptives are safe and effective for preventing pregnancy. • LNG and UPA pills reduce the risk of pregnancy by 85% or more when used promptly. • The copper IUD is the most effective emergency contraceptive, with a failure rate of less than 1%. 4. Eligibility for Use • Emergency contraceptives can be used by any woman of reproductive age, including adolescents. • There are no medical contraindications for the use of oral emergency contraceptive pills. • The copper IUD may be unsuitable for women with certain uterine abnormalities or infections. 5. Limitations of Emergency Contraception • ECs do not protect against sexually transmitted infections (STIs), including HIV. • They are not as effective as regular contraceptive methods for preventing pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of quadruple test
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Inhibin B Inhibin A is a part of quadruple test. The quad test (also called the quadruple marker test or quad screen) is a prenatal screening test performed during the second trimester of pregnancy. It assesses the risk of certain chromosomal abnormalities and neural tube defects in the fetus by analyzing specific markers in the mother’s blood. Key Components of the Quad Test The quad test measures four biochemical markers in maternal serum: 1. Alpha-fetoprotein (AFP): • A protein produced by the fetal liver and yolk sac. • Abnormal levels can indicate: • High AFP: Potential neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida, anencephaly) or abdominal wall defects. • Low AFP: Risk of chromosomal abnormalities like Down syndrome (trisomy 21) or Edwards syndrome (trisomy 18). 2. Human Chorionic Gonadotropin (hCG): • A hormone produced by the placenta. • Abnormally high levels may be associated with Down syndrome, while low levels may suggest Edwards syndrome. 3. Unconjugated Estriol (uE3): • A hormone produced by both the fetus and the placenta. • Low levels can indicate chromosomal abnormalities such as Down syndrome or Edwards syndrome. 4. Inhibin A: • A hormone produced by the placenta. • Elevated levels are associated with increased risk of Down syndrome. When is the Test Performed? • The quad test is typically performed between 15 and 22 weeks of gestation, with the optimal time being 16–18 weeks. Purpose and Interpretation The quad test provides a risk assessment rather than a definitive diagnosis. It calculates the probability of certain conditions based on the measured biomarkers, maternal age, gestational age, weight, and other factors. Conditions Screened: 1. Down Syndrome (Trisomy 21): • Associated with: • Low AFP and uE3 • High hCG and inhibin A 2. Edwards Syndrome (Trisomy 18): • Associated with: • Low AFP, hCG, and uE3 • Normal or slightly elevated inhibin A 3. Neural Tube Defects: • Elevated AFP may indicate spina bifida or anencephaly. Risk Assessment: • Results are presented as a numerical risk ratio (e.g., 1 in 1,000 or 1 in 50). • A positive result means the fetus is at a higher risk for a condition, warranting further diagnostic testing. • A negative result indicates a lower risk, but it does not eliminate the possibility of these conditions. Factors That Influence Results The accuracy of the test depends on several factors, including: • Gestational age: Errors in dating can affect marker levels. • Maternal weight: Higher weight can dilute serum marker levels. • Multiple pregnancies: Twin or triplet pregnancies can alter marker levels. • Diabetes: Can lead to lower levels of AFP. • Race and ethnicity: Normal marker ranges vary among different populations. Follow-Up Tests If the quad test indicates a high risk, further diagnostic tests may be recommended: 1. Ultrasound: To confirm gestational age or check for physical abnormalities. 2. Amniocentesis: To analyze amniotic fluid for chromosomal or neural tube defects. 3. Cell-free DNA (cfDNA) testing: A more specific screening for chromosomal abnormalities. Advantages • Non-invasive and simple blood test. • Can provide early risk assessment for certain conditions. Limitations • Screening test, not diagnostic: A positive result only indicates increased risk, not a definitive diagnosis. • False positives and negatives can occur. • Limited scope: Does not detect all fetal abnormalities or conditions. The quad test is an important part of prenatal care, offering valuable information about fetal health and guiding further investigations or interventions.

questions.text: A G 2 P0+0+1 woman with 35+3 weeks pregnancy with BPD -34 weeks, AC-30 weeks, HC - 33+4 weeks and AFI - 5 . Placenta is grade 3 Previa. And there is absent end diastolic flow. What is the next step of management ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Terminate immediately Absent end diastolic flow & the pregnancy has crossed 34 weeks ? immediate termination of pregnancy. Timing of Delivery The decision to deliver depends on gestational age, fetal well-being, and the severity of Doppler abnormalities. Preterm Pregnancy (<34 weeks): • Conservative management may be attempted if: • The fetus shows no signs of distress (normal biophysical profile and NST). • There is no progression to REDF or ductus venosus abnormalities. • Interventions: • Administer corticosteroids (betamethasone or dexamethasone) to promote fetal lung maturity. • Consider magnesium sulfate for neuroprotection if delivery is anticipated before 32 weeks. • Hospitalize for close maternal and fetal monitoring. Late Preterm (34–36 weeks): • Delivery is typically recommended if AEDF persists, even in the absence of fetal distress, as the risks of continuing the pregnancy may outweigh the benefits. Term Pregnancy (?37 weeks): • Delivery is generally recommended as AEDF at term indicates significant placental insufficiency. Indications for Immediate Delivery • Reverse End-Diastolic Flow (REDF) in the umbilical artery beyond 30-32 weeks • Abnormal Doppler findings in the ductus venosus (e.g., absent or reversed a-wave). • Persistent non-reassuring fetal heart rate patterns (e.g., decelerations, reduced variability). • Severe oligohydramnios (AFI <5 cm). • Worsening maternal conditions (e.g., severe preeclampsia, HELLP syndrome).

choices.text: Blue cells in Nile Blue Test

questions.text: All of the following indicated fetal lung maturity except?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Blue cells in Nile Blue Test Orange cells [>20%] in NBT are seen indicating lung maturation. Phosphatidyl glycerol : Best test, can be done on a contaminated sample with blood or meconium. TDx analyser measures surfactant : albumin ratio. Tests of fetal lung maturation are used to assess whether a fetus’s lungs are mature enough to function independently outside the womb. These tests are particularly valuable when preterm delivery is anticipated, as they help evaluate the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome (RDS). Key Components of Fetal Lung Maturation Testing Fetal lung maturation depends on the production of surfactant by type II pneumocytes in the fetal lungs. Surfactant reduces surface tension in the alveoli and prevents their collapse during respiration. 1. Lecithin-to-Sphingomyelin (L/S) Ratio • Principle: • Lecithin and sphingomyelin are phospholipids present in amniotic fluid. • Lecithin increases with fetal lung maturity, while sphingomyelin remains relatively constant. • Procedure: • Measured from amniotic fluid obtained by amniocentesis. • Interpretation: • L/S ratio ? 2.0 indicates fetal lung maturity. • L/S ratio 50,000/µL indicates lung maturity. • LBC < 15,000/µL suggests immaturity. • Advantages: • Rapid, inexpensive, and less affected by contamination. 5. Nile Blue Sulfate Test • Principle: • Assesses lipid content in amniotic fluid. Staining of lipid-laden cells indicates lung maturity. • Procedure: • Amniotic fluid is mixed with Nile blue sulfate dye, which stains lipid-containing cells orange. • Interpretation: • High proportion of orange-stained cells (fat-laden cells) indicates lung maturity. 6. Shake Test (Foam Stability Test) • Principle: • Determines the presence of surfactant by assessing foam formation in amniotic fluid mixed with ethanol. • Procedure: • Amniotic fluid is shaken with ethanol. • Foam formation is observed. • Interpretation: • Stable foam ring after 15 minutes indicates adequate surfactant and lung maturity. • Absence of foam suggests lung immaturity. • Advantages: • Simple and quick. • Limitations: • Semi-quantitative and less reliable compared to other tests.

questions.text: A 25-years-old women underwent induced ovulation. On USG, ovary showed 8 follicles. Serum estradol level was 800 pg/ml. What is the next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Retrieve follicles 1 mature follicle produces 200pg of estrogen. The above scenario is a normal response. If more than equal to 2 follicles seen bigger than 18mm ? give inj. HCG & after 36 hours retrieve the follicles [called as ovum pickup :USG guided procedure]. 1. Follicular Criteria • Number of Follicles: • At least 2 mature follicles (?17–18 mm in diameter) should be present. • If there are >20 follicles, the risk of ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome (OHSS) increases, and an agonist trigger (GnRH agonist) may be considered as an alternative. • Follicular Size: • Follicles should ideally measure: • ?17–18 mm: Considered mature and capable of yielding a mature oocyte. • 12–16 mm: Intermediate follicles may also contribute to retrieval but are less likely to contain mature eggs. • The trigger is typically given when a cohort of at least 2–3 dominant follicles reaches 17 mm or larger. 2. Estradiol (E2) Levels Estradiol levels correlate with the number of mature follicles and their quality: • Expected E2 Level per Mature Follicle: • Approximately 200–300 pg/mL per mature follicle (?17 mm in diameter). • Minimum Threshold: • ?1,000 pg/mL total E2 is usually required to justify hCG administration, though this varies depending on follicle size and count. • Upper Limit to Avoid OHSS: • If E2 levels exceed 3,500–4,000 pg/mL, the risk of OHSS increases. • In these cases, alternatives to hCG (e.g., GnRH agonist trigger) are preferred. For patients at high risk of OHSS: • Estradiol Levels: If E2 >3,500 pg/mL and/or more than 20 follicles are present, an alternative trigger (GnRH agonist) may be used, particularly in cycles where a freeze-all strategy is planned.

If it is less than 25mm : Cervical cerclage is put along with giving progesterone. Cervical Length (CL) Measurement • Transvaginal Ultrasound (TVUS) is the gold standard for assessing cervical length. • Criteria for considering cerclage: • Short Cervix: • Cervical length 1 cm with visible or bulging membranes before 24 weeks of gestation. • Immediate intervention required to prevent fetal loss.

questions.text: A female come to gynae OPD for preconceptual counselling, with history of two second trimester abortions. What is the most important investigation for her:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Hysteroscopy TVS is a screening test, First test to be done [next step if asked]. Most important investigation here is hysteroscopy. that hysteroscopy is a highly valuable investigation in cases of recurrent second-trimester losses, particularly in a non-pregnant state, as it allows both diagnosis and potential treatment of uterine abnormalities. Let’s analyze the situation further. Hysteroscopy has following advantages 1. Direct Visualization of the Uterine Cavity: • Hysteroscopy allows direct inspection of the uterine cavity, which is crucial for identifying: • Uterine anomalies (e.g., septate or bicornuate uterus). • Intrauterine adhesions (Asherman syndrome). • Submucous fibroids or polyps that may interfere with implantation or pregnancy maintenance. • TVS may suggest uterine pathology, but hysteroscopy provides a definitive diagnosis and the opportunity for intervention. 2. Therapeutic Potential: • If an abnormality is detected, hysteroscopy can simultaneously treat the condition (e.g., resecting a septum or adhesions), improving the chances of a successful future pregnancy. 3. Significant History of Losses: • The history of second-trimester abortions strongly suggests anatomical or structural issues, such as uterine anomalies, which are best evaluated by hysteroscopy rather than TVS alone.

questions.text: A pregnant female delivered a baby with normal expulsion of an intact placenta. After half hour she started bleeding per vaginaly. On examination she was hypotensive and boggy mass is palpated per abdomen. USG showed retained placental tissues. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Placenta succenturiata 1 smaller lobe left inside : Placenta succenturiata → presents as PPH. VASA PREVIA [fetal blood] : has an association with velamentous & succenturiate placenta → they can cause both APH [by vasa previa] & PPH. Apt test is done in vasa previa to differentiate between maternal & fetal blood → fetal blood is resistant to denaturation, color will be retained. Management of vasa previa is emergency cesarean section

questions.text: Following are the features of the color of normal amniotic fluid during delivery?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Clear colorless to pale yellow Normal amniotic fluid : colorless At term: turbid/yellow amniotic fluid Golden amniotic fluid : Rh incompatibility Green : Meconium aspiration Dark brown: IUD DARK ALTERED BLOOD : ABRUPTION At term, the characteristics of amniotic fluid can vary depending on the stage of pregnancy, fetal development, and other factors. Below are the typical features of amniotic fluid at term: 1. Color • Normal: • Pale yellow to clear is considered normal at term. • Slightly yellowish fluid may result from fetal urine and skin secretions. • Abnormal Colors: • Meconium-stained fluid: Green or brown, indicating meconium passage, which can suggest fetal distress or post-maturity. • Bloody fluid: May indicate placental abruption or trauma. • Dark yellow or amber: Suggests bilirubin, often due to hemolysis (e.g., Rh incompatibility). • Cloudy or purulent: Can indicate intra-amniotic infection (chorioamnionitis). 2. Consistency • Normal: • At term, the fluid may contain flakes or particles, which are shed fetal skin cells (vernix caseosa) and lanugo (fine fetal hair). • Flakes give the fluid a slightly turbid appearance but are normal. • Abnormal: • Turbid with foul odor: Indicates possible infection. • Thick, particulate meconium: Higher risk of meconium aspiration syndrome. 3. Volume • Normal amniotic fluid volume at term is approximately 800 mL. • Oligohydramnios: Reduced fluid volume (24 cm amniotic fluid index), associated with maternal diabetes, fetal anomalies, or infections.

questions.text: 28 weeks gestation lady presents with fever, acute pain abdomen and mild leucocytosis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Red degeneration of fibroid Red degeneration of fibroid (also known as carneous degeneration) is a type of degenerative change that occurs in uterine fibroids (leiomyomas), usually during pregnancy. It is characterized by hemorrhagic infarction within the fibroid due to compromised blood supply. This condition is typically painful and self-limiting. Key Features of Red Degeneration 1. Pathophysiology • Blood supply compromise: • Fibroids grow in response to estrogen, especially during pregnancy. • The increased size of the fibroid can outstrip its blood supply. • Venous obstruction or arterial thrombosis leads to hemorrhagic infarction. • Necrosis: • Hemorrhage and tissue necrosis occur within the fibroid, leading to acute symptoms. 2. Risk Factors • Pregnancy: • Red degeneration is most common during the second trimester of pregnancy due to rapid fibroid growth under the influence of high estrogen and progesterone levels. • Large fibroids: • Larger fibroids are more likely to undergo degeneration as they require greater vascular support. • Subserosal and intramural fibroids: • These are more prone to degeneration due to their location and blood supply pattern. 3. Clinical Features • Pain: • Sudden onset of localized, sharp, or cramping abdominal pain over the fibroid. • Pain may radiate to the back, flank, or thighs. • Tenderness: • The fibroid may become tender on palpation. • Fever: • Low-grade fever can occur due to inflammation associated with necrosis. • Nausea and vomiting: • Commonly accompany severe pain. • Uterine irritability: • Can mimic preterm labor in pregnant women. 4. Diagnosis • Clinical examination: • Tender, firm, irregular uterine mass may be palpable. • Ultrasound (USG): • Heterogeneous echotexture of the fibroid. • Possible peripheral cystic changes or hypoechoic areas due to necrosis. • Doppler studies may show reduced or absent vascular flow within the fibroid. • MRI (if necessary): • Helpful in distinguishing red degeneration from other causes of pain (e.g., torsion or rupture). • Shows hyperintense areas on T1-weighted images due to hemorrhage. 5. Management • Conservative management is usually sufficient, as the condition is self-limiting. • Analgesics: Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain relief. • Hydration and bed rest: Supportive care to reduce symptoms. • Antipyretics: For low-grade fever. • Antispasmodics: To alleviate uterine irritability in pregnant women. • Monitoring: • Regular follow-up to ensure symptom resolution. • Fetal monitoring in pregnant women to rule out complications like preterm labor. • Surgical intervention: • Rarely indicated, but myomectomy may be considered postpartum or if there are persistent complications.

questions.text: Which one is not possible-
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DCMA In the context of twin pregnancies: MCMA: Monochorionic Monoamniotic (twins share both the same chorion and amniotic sac) MCDA: Monochorionic Diamniotic (twins share the same chorion but have separate amniotic sacs) DCDA: Dichorionic Diamniotic (twins have separate chorions and separate amniotic sacs)MADC does not correspond to a recognized classification of twin pregnancies.

questions.text: In a hypertensive patient presenting with PPH which drug is contraindicated
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Methylergometrine In a hypertensive patient presenting with postpartum haemorrhage (PPH) the drug contraindicate is Methylergometrine. Methylergometrine (also known as Methergine) is contraindicated in hypertensive patients because it can cause severe hypertension due to its vasoconstrictive properties.

questions.text: A G2 P1 female with 6 wks amenorrhea presents with bleeding pv, hypotension. She has pain in abdomen and on p/v examination cervical motion tenderness is present. On usg free fluid is present in right paracolic gutter. What is the most probable diagnosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ruptured ectopic The combination of 6 weeks of amenorrhea, vaginal bleeding, hypotension, abdominal pain, cervical motion tenderness, and free fluid in the right paracolic gutter strongly suggests a ruptured ectopic pregnancy. Free fluid in the abdomen, particularly in the context of hypotension and abdominal pain, suggests internal bleeding. In early pregnancy, this is highly suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

questions.text: 18 wks pregnant female presents with high risk of NTD and low risk of trisomy 21 on quadruple test-what to do next
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anomaly scan In a pregnant female at 18 weeks with a high risk of neural tube defects (NTD) and a low risk of trisomy 21 based on the quadruple test, the next best step is Anomaly scan. An anomaly scan, also known as a detailed or level II ultrasound, is typically performed between 18 and 22 weeks of gestation. This scan is used to detect structural anomalies, including neural tube defects, and is the appropriate next step to further evaluate the risk of NTD. Amniocentesis can also detect neural tube defects but is usually reserved for confirmation if anomalies are detected on the ultrasound.

questions.text: A 32 year old female at 36 weeks of pregancy presents with BP 170/100 mm of hg, visual disturbances, headache, urine protein 3+-what will be the next best step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Management of Impending Eclampsia Impending eclampsia refers to a clinical condition in preeclampsia where a woman exhibits warning signs and symptoms suggesting the imminent development of eclampsia (generalized tonic-clonic seizures). Prompt and effective management is essential to prevent maternal and fetal complications. Clinical Features of Impending Eclampsia • Severe or persistent headache (unresponsive to analgesics). • Visual disturbances (e.g., blurred vision, scotomas, diplopia). • Hyperreflexia or clonus. • Persistent epigastric or right upper quadrant pain (suggestive of liver involvement). • Rising blood pressure (?160/110 mmHg). • Severe proteinuria or oliguria. • Symptoms of cerebral irritability. Management Steps 1. Immediate Stabilization • Environment: • Admit the patient to a high-dependency or labor ward with continuous monitoring. • Ensure a quiet, darkened environment to minimize sensory stimulation (which can precipitate seizures). • Monitoring: • Regular monitoring of: • Blood pressure (frequent checks or continuous monitoring). • Oxygen saturation. • Urine output (via catheterization to assess oliguria). • Reflexes and clonus (indicators of cerebral irritability). • Fetal heart rate (via cardiotocography). 2. Seizure Prophylaxis • Magnesium Sulfate is the drug of choice for preventing seizures in impending eclampsia: • Loading dose: • 4g of magnesium sulfate intravenously over 10-20 minutes. • Maintenance dose: 5 g intramuscularly (IM) in each buttock every 4 hours. • Monitor for toxicity: • Check for deep tendon reflexes, respiratory rate (>12 breaths/min), and urine output (>30 mL/hour). • Antidote: Calcium gluconate (1 g IV over 10 minutes). 3. Blood Pressure Control • Aim to maintain systolic BP <160 mmHg and diastolic BP <110 mmHg to reduce the risk of stroke and organ damage. • Antihypertensives: • Labetalol (first-line): • 20 mg IV bolus, repeated every 10–15 minutes as needed (max dose 220 mg). • Hydralazine: • 5–10 mg IV bolus over 10 minutes; repeat every 20–30 minutes as needed. • Nifedipine: • 10 mg oral immediate-release; can be repeated after 30 minutes. • Avoid excessive lowering of blood pressure to prevent reduced placental perfusion. 4. Delivery Planning • Delivery is the definitive treatment for impending eclampsia but must be balanced with gestational age and maternal/fetal status. • Mode of delivery: • Vaginal delivery is preferred if the cervix is favorable and induction is feasible. • Cesarean section is indicated for maternal or fetal instability or an unfavorable cervix. 5. Postpartum Care • Magnesium sulfate: • Continue for 24 hours postpartum or until symptoms resolve. • Blood pressure monitoring: • Antihypertensives should be continued postpartum if hypertension persists. • Monitor for complications such as pulmonary edema, renal dysfunction, or recurrent seizures.

questions.text: An female with O negative blood group and husband B positive was given Anti D at 28 weeks. What is the criteria for giving Anti D post partum
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) DCT negative, Baby Rh +ve The correct criterion for giving Anti-D immunoglobulin postpartum is DCT negative, Baby Rh +ve. Anti-D immunoglobulin is given to Rh-negative mothers to prevent Rh sensitization, which can occur if the baby is Rh-positive. The direct Coombs test (DCT) is typically used to detect antibodies already bound to red blood cells, indicating sensitization. If the DCT is negative and the baby is Rh-positive, it means the mother has not been sensitized, and administering Anti-D will help prevent future sensitization.

questions.text: At what vertebral level is ischial spine
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Coccyx Ischial spine level is corresponding to the lower border of acetabulum. Explanation: The ischial spine is a bony projection on the posterior aspect of the ischium (part of the pelvic bone). It serves as an important landmark in obstetrics and anatomy. • It is located approximately at the level of the coccyx in the pelvic cavity. • Clinically, it is palpated during vaginal examinations to assess pelvic dimensions or during procedures like pudendal nerve block. Other Options: • L4-L5 (A): This corresponds to the lumbar vertebrae in the lower back, far above the pelvic level. • L5 Body (B): This is still higher than the ischial spine and is part of the lumbar spine. • Spine of S3 (C): While closer to the pelvic region, the ischial spine is lower and closer to the coccyx.

questions.text: Which hormone has no role in fetal growth
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Growth hormone has no direct role in fetal growth. Explanation: • Growth Hormone (GH): • GH has little to no role in fetal growth. This is because the fetal pituitary is not the primary regulator of growth during intrauterine development. • Fetal growth is largely dependent on other hormones like insulin, IGF-1, and thyroxine. • Insulin (B): • Insulin is a key hormone for fetal growth. • It regulates nutrient availability and promotes growth by enhancing the anabolic effects of nutrients. • IGF-1 (C): • Insulin-like Growth Factor 1 (IGF-1) is crucial for fetal growth. • It mediates the growth-promoting effects of insulin and is directly involved in cellular growth and differentiation. • Thyroxine (D): • Thyroxine (T4) plays a significant role in fetal growth and brain development, particularly in the second and third trimesters.

questions.text: Which is most potent natural estrogen
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Estradiol Estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen in terms of its biological activity. This is the most potent natural estrogen. It has the highest binding affinity to estrogen receptors and exerts strong biological effects, particularly during the reproductive years. It plays a crucial role in the development and maintenance of female reproductive tissues and secondary sexual characteristics.

questions.text: All are used to diagnose IUGR except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Uterine artery Pulsatality index < 95th percentile A uterine artery pulsatility index (PI) < 95th percentile is generally not associated with intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR). In fact, a PI greater than the 95th percentile can be an indicator of poor placental perfusion and potential growth restriction. The other options (a, b, and c) are commonly used to diagnose IUGR: Absent end diastolic flow on umbilical artery: This is a significant marker of severe placental insufficiency and is associated with IUGR. Estimated Fetal Weight (EFW) < 3rd percentile: This is a direct indicator of IUGR. Abdominal circumference (AC) < 3rd percentile: This is a key measurement used in diagnosing IUGR.

questions.text: A G2 P1-29 year old female delivered a baby but the baby died in 2 days due o medical reasons. What drug will u advise to stop breast milk secretion
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Cabergoline Cabergoline is a dopamine agonist that inhibits prolactin secretion and is commonly used to suppress lactation. It is effective and has fewer side effects compared to other options. - Ergot alkaloids can suppress lactation but are less commonly used due to their side effect profile. - Dopamine itself is not used directly for lactation suppression. - Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analogue used for other indications such as inducing labor or treating postpartum hemorrhage, but it is not used to suppress lactation.

questions.text: What is the reason for increased blood volume at term in pregnancy
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) In pregnancy, increased blood volume occurs due to a combination of fluid retention and the hormonal effects of aldosterone and estrogen. Here’s a detailed breakdown: 1. Increased Fluid Retention (A): • The kidneys retain more sodium and water during pregnancy, leading to an increase in plasma volume. • This fluid retention helps meet the increased circulatory demands of the growing uterus, placenta, and fetus. 2. Action of Aldosterone and Estrogen (B): • Aldosterone: • Stimulates renal sodium and water retention, contributing to the expansion of blood volume. • Estrogen: • Increases renin activity, which stimulates the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS), further promoting sodium and water retention. • It also promotes vascular changes to accommodate increased blood flow.

choices.text: Reposition of uterus without removing placenta
Shift to Ot and insert uterus back under GA

questions.text: Management of uterine inversion with placenta attached next step
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Reposition without removing the placenta Explanation: Uterine inversion is a rare but life-threatening obstetric emergency where the uterus turns inside out, often accompanied by significant hemorrhage and shock. When the placenta is still attached, the management must prioritize repositioning the uterus first, without removing the placenta, for the following reasons: 1. Why Reposition Before Placental Removal? • Repositioning the uterus before placenta removal reduces hemorrhage: • Attempting to remove the placenta while the uterus is inverted increases bleeding because the uterus is unable to contract effectively when inverted. • Restoring the uterus to its normal anatomical position allows it to contract and reduce bleeding. 2. Physiological Rationale: • The inverted uterus cannot contract properly, leading to atony and massive hemorrhage. • Repositioning the uterus restores normal uterine anatomy, facilitating contraction and minimizing further blood loss. Steps in Management 1. Immediate Actions: • Assess and stabilize the patient: IV fluids, oxygen, and management of shock. • Avoid excessive traction on the cord or placenta, as this can worsen the inversion. 2. Reposition the Uterus Without Removing the Placenta: • Use manual repositioning (Johnson’s maneuver) to push the fundus back into the abdominal cavity. • Avoid pulling or separating the placenta during this process. 3. After Successful Repositioning: • Once the uterus is repositioned and contracts, attempt controlled placental removal. • Administer uterotonics (e.g., oxytocin) to maintain uterine contraction and prevent re-inversion. 4. If Manual Repositioning Fails: • Shift to the operating room (OT) for repositioning under general anesthesia (GA) or surgical intervention. Why Not the Other Options? • A) Remove placenta and reposition: • Removing the placenta first increases bleeding and worsens uterine atony. • C) Shift to OT and reposition under GA: • While GA may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step should be manual repositioning without GA whenever possible. • D) Separate placenta first: • Separating the placenta before repositioning leads to massive hemorrhage and increases maternal morbidity.

questions.text: Woman is 3cm dilated, 70% effaced on p/v exam bag of worms is felt
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Management of Cord Presentation Cord presentation refers to a situation where the umbilical cord lies in front of or adjacent to the presenting part of the fetus but remains within the intact membranes (as opposed to cord prolapse, where the cord descends into or beyond the vagina). Cord presentation is a high-risk obstetric emergency because it may lead to cord prolapse during rupture of membranes, compromising fetal oxygenation. Immediate Management The management of cord presentation depends on several factors, including gestational age, presence of labor, and fetal viability. 1. Antenatal Period (Cord Presentation Diagnosed on Ultrasound) If cord presentation is identified before labor or membrane rupture, the primary aim is to prevent complications: • Hospitalization: • Admit the patient for close monitoring, especially if preterm labor or rupture of membranes is suspected. • Modified Bed Rest: • Advise bed rest in a Trendelenburg position (head-down tilt) to reduce pressure on the cord. • Fetal Surveillance: • Perform regular non-stress tests (NSTs) and biophysical profiles (BPPs) to monitor fetal well-being. • Corticosteroids: • Administer antenatal corticosteroids (e.g., betamethasone or dexamethasone) if the gestational age is <34 weeks to promote fetal lung maturity. • Avoid Vaginal Examinations: • To prevent rupture of membranes or displacement of the cord. • Plan for Delivery: • Elective cesarean section is planned near term if the cord presentation persists. 2. Intrapartum Period (Membranes Intact) If cord presentation is diagnosed during labor or with intact membranes: • Avoid Artificial Rupture of Membranes (ARM): • Rupturing the membranes can precipitate cord prolapse. • Cesarean Delivery: • Immediate cesarean section is recommended to avoid the risk of cord prolapse and fetal compromise. 3. Intrapartum Period (Membranes Ruptured) If cord presentation progresses to cord prolapse (cord visible or palpable in the vagina after membrane rupture), urgent measures are required: 1. Relieve Cord Compression: • Place the mother in a Trendelenburg or knee-chest position to reduce pressure on the cord. • Manually elevate the presenting part off the cord (use sterile gloves). • Avoid handling or manipulating the cord excessively to prevent vasospasm. 2. Oxygen and IV Fluids: • Administer oxygen to the mother and start IV fluids to optimize placental perfusion. 3. Emergency Cesarean Section: • Perform immediate cesarean delivery to prevent fetal hypoxia or death.

choices.text: Chances of bowel injury due to PAS
Chances of bladder injury due to PAS
Chances of hysterectomy due to PAS

questions.text: G6L1A3 she has had 2 previous CS, Which will not be taken as consent
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Chances of bowel injury due to PAS. Explanation: Placenta Accreta Spectrum (PAS) disorders, including placenta accreta, increta, and percreta, involve abnormal adherence or invasion of the placenta into the uterine wall. These conditions are significant risks in patients with prior cesarean sections (CS), especially with multiple previous CS. Why “Chances of Bowel Injury Due to PAS” Is Not Taken as Consent: • Bowel injury is not a common or direct complication of PAS. • While bowel injury can occur during cesarean delivery in general (especially with dense adhesions from prior surgeries), it is not specifically related to PAS itself. • Therefore, it is not routinely included as a risk when counseling for PAS. What Risks Must Be Included in Consent for PAS? The following risks are directly associated with PAS and must be part of informed consent: 1. B) Chances of Bladder Injury Due to PAS: • PAS disorders (especially percreta) often involve invasion into the bladder, leading to a high risk of bladder injury during surgery. • Bladder dissection or repair is frequently required. 2. C) Chances of Hysterectomy Due to PAS: • A high percentage of PAS cases require a hysterectomy to control bleeding and remove the abnormally invasive placenta. • This is a major risk that must be clearly communicated. 3. D) Chances of Blood Transfusion: • Massive hemorrhage is common in PAS cases, necessitating blood transfusion in most cases. • Multidisciplinary planning for blood products and hemostatic agents is essential.

questions.text: If we ligate artery for PPH then which will serve uterus with anastomosis
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Yes, after uterine artery ligation to control postpartum hemorrhage (PPH), the uterus receives blood supply through collateral circulation primarily from the ovarian artery and, to a lesser extent, the artery of the round ligament. Here’s how these vessels contribute: 1. Ovarian Artery • Primary Collateral Source: • The ovarian artery is a direct branch of the abdominal aorta. • It anastomoses with the uterine artery at the uterine cornua and along the fallopian tube. • After uterine artery ligation, the ovarian artery becomes the major contributor to uterine blood supply. 2. Artery of the Round Ligament (Sampson’s Artery) • Secondary Collateral Source: • The artery of the round ligament is a small branch of the external iliac artery or inferior epigastric artery. • It travels within the round ligament and anastomoses with the uterine artery near the uterine fundus. • While its contribution to uterine perfusion is minor compared to the ovarian artery, it does provide an additional route for blood flow. 3. Additional Collateral Sources • Contralateral Uterine Artery: • The uterine arteries form an anastomotic network across the midline, particularly at the cervical level. • Vaginal Artery: • This artery contributes to the lower uterine segment and anastomoses with the uterine artery. • Internal Pudendal Artery: • Supplies parts of the lower uterus and vagina indirectly.

questions.text: A patient came with bipolar disorder, she is pregnant in third trimester and she is on daily 750mg of lithium. Now she is well controlled. What will you advise
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Physiological Changes in the Third Trimester: • Increased renal clearance of lithium occurs due to physiological changes during pregnancy, particularly increased glomerular filtration rate (GFR). This may lead to reduced serum lithium levels. • As a result, the dose of lithium may need to be increased in the third trimester to maintain therapeutic levels. 2. Lithium Monitoring: • Regular serum lithium level monitoring is essential to ensure the dose remains within the therapeutic range (0.6–1.2 mEq/L). • Monitoring should be done more frequently (e.g., every 1–2 weeks) in the third trimester. 3. Risk of Toxicity Near Delivery: • Postpartum, renal clearance decreases to pre-pregnancy levels, leading to a risk of lithium toxicity if the dose is not adjusted down after delivery. Recommendations for Lithium Dose in the Third Trimester • Increase the dose of lithium (if required) based on serum levels to maintain therapeutic efficacy. • Target lower therapeutic range (0.6–0.8 mEq/L) to balance efficacy and reduce toxicity risks. • Monitor for signs of toxicity (e.g., tremors, nausea, diarrhea, ataxia).

questions.text: Which viral infection is not teratogenic
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Certain viral infections can cause congenital malformations (teratogenesis) if acquired during pregnancy, especially in the first trimester. Let’s examine each option: 1. Varicella (A): • Teratogenic: • Infection with varicella-zoster virus (VZV) in the first or second trimester can cause congenital varicella syndrome, characterized by limb hypoplasia, microcephaly, and skin scarring. 2. Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) (B): • Not teratogenic: • While neonatal herpes (from transmission during delivery) is a serious condition, herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection during pregnancy does not typically cause congenital malformations (teratogenesis). • However, HSV can lead to preterm labor or pregnancy loss in rare cases. 3. Cytomegalovirus (CMV) (C): • Teratogenic: • Congenital CMV infection can result in microcephaly, sensorineural hearing loss, chorioretinitis, and developmental delays. It is the most common cause of congenital viral infections. 4. Rubella (D): • Teratogenic: • Infection in the first trimester causes congenital rubella syndrome, leading to cataracts, heart defects (e.g., patent ductus arteriosus), sensorineural deafness, and microcephaly.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman, G2P1L1, comes for a quadruple test at 16 weeks. Which of the following is not included in the quadruple test?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) The quadruple test (or quad screen) is a standard prenatal screening test performed during the second trimester of pregnancy. Its purpose is to assess the risk of certain fetal abnormalities, primarily Down syndrome (Trisomy 21), Trisomy 18, and neural tube defects. The test achieves this by measuring the levels of four specific biochemical markers in the mother's blood. These markers are: • AFP (Alpha-fetoprotein): Produced by the fetal liver. • Unconjugated Estriol (uE3): A weak estrogen produced by the placenta and fetal liver. • hCG (human Chorionic Gonadotropin): A hormone produced by the placenta. (Often measured as the beta subunit, i.e., Beta hCG). • Inhibin A: A glycoprotein hormone produced by the placent
